title: The Winter 2026 NYFW Trends Iâ€™m Most Excited For
text:
The Winter 2026 NYFW Trends Iâ€™m Most Excited For

Over the last week, New York City proved its status as a fashion capital of the world, with talented designers showcasing creative collections on the runways, in the streets, and on our feeds. From â€œlet them eat cakeâ€ aesthetics and double-duty bags to fringed frocks and leather opera gloves, New York Fashion Week brought statement fashion trends and serious 2026 outfit inspo to the forefront.

In order to get the front-row scoop on what will be huge for the fall and winter of 2026, I attended so many fashion shows and presentations that my heels hurt and phone was always on the brink of losing power. The endeavor was more than worth it because I found the standout trends (that I think you can start implementing into your wardrobe while itâ€™s still cold!). The wonderfully disheveled indie sleaze look and head-to-toe animal prints that dominated New Yorkâ€™s runways are especially great for party looks, while brooches and headwear can add flair to any winter outfit.

Ahead, see which brands â€” from New York staples like Tory Burch to NYFW debuts like that of designer-denim staple 7 For All Mankind â€” took on similar trends in their own unique points of view. Then shop styles to get the looks.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Vintage-InspiredÂ BroochesÂ forÂ Today

Wondering what the stand-out accessory of the A/W 2026 shows were? It wasnâ€™t just one shoe trend or a particular purse or a statement necklace. It was the brooch. Ranging from metal sculptures from the likes of Caroline Herrera, Cult Gaia, and Tory Burch; crystal cascades courtesy of Collina Strada; 3D glass florals by Caroline Zimbalist; and Sergio Hudsonâ€™s fabric-covered designs, many brands put their seal of approval on a vintage staple.

These modern designs might look out of place in your grandmotherâ€™s jewelry box (but that doesnâ€™t mean she wonâ€™t want to borrow your baubles from time to time!). Pin them to your sweater, winter coat, or to secure your scarf for fashion and function.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Animals Gone Wild

I can confidently say that animal prints will never go out of style. In fact, theyâ€™ve essentially become neutrals that can seamlessly integrate into everyoneâ€™s wardrobes today. This season, brands like Anna Sui, Norma Kamali, Ralph Lauren, and Ulla Johnson tapped the fan-favorite cheetah and leopard prints. Looking to find inspiration from other corners of the animal kingdom? Kim Shui and Markarian introduced tiger prints, while Kate Hundley and Sergio Hudson offered snakeskin sets, and Bronx and Banco sent out a zebra purse.

Animal illustrations were also big sources of inspiration, as Alix of Bohemia featured a whole zoo worth of animal prints and embellishments (think: giraffes and monkeys!). Swans also popped up across Tanner Fletcher outerwear and Aknvas button-downs if avian-inspired looks are more your style.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Grunge & Indie Sleaze Scene

For those of us who crave nostalgia, itâ€™s exciting to note that the â€˜90s and early 2000s have never been more back! Specifically, moody grunge and indie sleaze party-girl aesthetics are having a moment, with dark palettes, messy styling, and even disheveled, slept-in hair (look no further than Collina Stradaâ€™s models for proof). Plaid prints featured heavily in the anchor pieces of several collections, including Coachâ€™s youthful blazers as well as Collina Stradaâ€™s and Private Policyâ€™s dresses.

The 7 For All Mankind runway show was also a master class in early-aughts styling, down to the energy and even the modelsâ€™ viral walks. Think, lots of layering, all-denim-everything, skinny scarves, platform pumps, jumbo shoulder bags, and chunky jewelry all together â€” because in this case, more is more.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Hat Attack

Bundling up in the cold has never looked so chic. Hats and headpieces served as the cherry on top of this seasonâ€™s runway looks, serving inspiration for right now and next winter. Designers especially made the case for having headwear for every outfit and event, no matter how casual or fancy. Designs included chic pillbox hats and caps that tie around the neck (Christian Cowan), fur trapper hats and headbands (Aknvas and Bronc and Banco), oversized knit silhouettes (Advisry), extra-long beanies (Private Policy), lace skull caps (Prabal Gurung and LaQuan Smith), and beaded head coverings (Jane Wade) across womenswear and menswear alike.

The impossibly stylish A$AP Rocky even wore a fur trapper to close out the NYFW debut of his brand AWGE, giving hats a celebrity stamp of approval!

DashDividers_1_500x100

All Laced Up

While the collections that New York Cityâ€™s designers showed this season werenâ€™t as stiff or structured as some in the past, lacing still showed up as a major throughline. For proof, look no further than Adeamâ€™s, Elena Velezâ€™s, and Meruert Tolegenâ€™s not-so-basic corsets and dresses.

Those seeking more casual interpretations of the trend can turn to Kate Hundleyâ€™s lace-up puffer jacket, which is proof that your winter puffer can not only not ruin your outfit; it can make your entire look. Gabe Gordonâ€™s lace-up knit skirt also feels as right for aprÃ¨s ski as it does for a Saturday athleisure look. Laces even made their way into the modelsâ€™ hair at Caroline Zimbalist as an unexpected hairstyle trend.

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

The 8 Color Trends That Will Reign Supreme In 2026

The 2026 Shoe Trends Dominating The Market

The Top 2026 Denim Trends Ask You to Take Up Space

title: Channel â€™80s Cool With These Karol G x Reebok Classic Relaunches
text:
Channel â€™80s Cool With These Karol G x Reebok Classic Relaunches With â€œBorn Classic. Worn For Life,â€ Reebok is bringing in a new iteration of the sneaker brandâ€™s long-favorite style â€” and for Karol G, whoâ€™s fronting the campaign, just wearing the latest drop is, literally, a dream come true.

In January, when the Colombian pop star was named Reebokâ€™s new global brand ambassador, Karol G â€” born Carolina Giraldo Navarro â€” told Complex that growing up in MedellÃ­n in the early 2000s, sheâ€™d get lost in reveries of herself walking around her school campus in a pair of Reebok Classics.Â 

â€œWearing Reeboks became a huge thing when I was at school, especially this Classic version. Having a pair felt like everything. I remember dreaming about them, imagining how it would feel to finally wear them and show them off,â€ she told the publication.Â 

The sneakers were so popular among Latine youth that Reebok even collaborated with the biggest star of reggaeton at the time, Daddy Yankee, for a â€œDYâ€ signature sneaker and apparel line in 2005.

Now, with reggaeton one of the most popular genres in the world and Karol G as one of its front-runners, itâ€™s her turn. And the Grammy award-winning singer isnâ€™t just wearing Reebok Classics like she dreamed â€” campaign photos of her in the 131-year-old footwear brand can be seen all over, from MedellÃ­n to the rest of the world.Â 

As part of â€œBorn Classic. Worn For Life,â€ the sports culture brand launched its most popular lifestyle sneakers crafted in 100% real, full-grain premium garment leather, including Club C 85 Vintage, Freestyle Lo, Workout Plus.Â 

And while the sneakers were just made available on February 18, WWD reported in late January that just the announcement of Karol G as Reebokâ€™s latest ambassador generated $1.1 million in Media Impact Value (MIV) in 48 hours for the footwear brand.Â 

Swipe to see what all the hype is about.

title: Tyra Banks Needs To Be Held Accountable. Sheâ€™s Also The Perfect Scapegoat
text:
Tyra Banks Needs To Be Held Accountable. Sheâ€™s Also The Perfect Scapegoat

Over the last few days, the social media firing squad has been aimed at Tyra Banks and the producers behind Americaâ€™s Next Top Model, the cultural phenomenon of a reality show that aired from 2003 to 2018 and spawned dozens of international spinoffs. Reality Check: Inside Americaâ€™s Next Top Model is proof that the more things change, the more they stay the same.

The Netflix docuseries, which premiered on February 11, featured firsthand accounts from models, including Ebony Haith (Cycle 1), Shandi Sullivan (Cycle 2) and Danielle Evans (Cycle 6) as well as judges Jay Manuel, J. Alexander and Nigel Barker. Through three episodes, viewers get a firsthand look at the exploitative conditions contestants were subjected to each cycle. That included extreme makeovers using plastic surgery and dental work, blackface and racist stereotypes as photoshoot themes and a sexual assault that was intentionally caught on film. Banks and former ANTM executive producer Ken Mok, who both served as executive producers for Reality Check, were also interviewed.

For 24 cycles, Banks was able to bully women into becoming the American ideal standard of what the â€œideal womanâ€ was at that time. And for millennials who were coming of age at the height of the show, it was not only appointment television; it was a rubric for how to become worthy of adoration.

ANTM was one of the first times millennials witnessed hyperfemininity politics on display in the media through a reality show competition. As a little Black girl from the Midwest, watching the women who looked like me on the show further ingrained a conditioning that was already at play: that, to the world, I could only be beautiful with conditions. With Reality Check, flashbacks of Ebonyâ€™s gorgeous skin being called dull and ashy came rushing to the forefront. Danielle Evans being pressured to close her gap influenced me to want braces (thank you for not acquiescing, mom). Watching judges dismiss the concerns of Tocarra Jones (Cycle 3), a full-figured woman from my hometown who I grew up looking up to, injured my confidence as I grew into my own curves.

And as a child, I was convinced Black girls couldnâ€™t show their hurt like Tiffany Richardson (Cycle 4) did, lest be seen as aggressive, ungrateful and undeserving.

â€œIt was very, very intense but you guys were demanding it, and so we kept pushing more and more and more,â€ Banks said in Reality Check.

Banks skirts accountability in an astonishingly delusional manner throughout the docuseries. The trauma this show left with these women â€” especially the sexual assault of Shandi, which the documentary doesnâ€™t name as such â€” was real, and Banks is to blame. At the same time, thereâ€™s some validity in her statement that we canâ€™t ignore. No, viewers didnâ€™t force Banks to exploit these women,Â  and much of the trauma they were subjected to has come into perspective only recently, but the buck doesnâ€™t stop with Banks or this show.

ANTM wasnâ€™t just a look into the exploitative extremes models experienced behind the scenes. It held a mirror up to the homogenous beauty standards that Americans celebrated in the early to mid aughts. The message was resounding: thin and white was right. And if you were a woman of color, you better adapt quickly if you want to get anywhere.

As we sit firmly in 2026, itâ€™s clear how wrong Banks and the producers were in their abuse of power. But whatâ€™s being overlooked is that history is repeating itself right before our eyes.

With social media, thereâ€™s an insurmountable pressure that comes with showing up as your best. And unlike in 2003, the feedback is in real time. With a growing amount of content creators and influencers relying on social media platforms for their livelihoods, it takes more time, energy and money than ever before to keep up with appearances. For many, thatâ€™s the difference between economic stability or missing out on opportunities.

Body positivity feels like a thing of the past as the idea of thinness reemerges as a status symbol and the demand for cosmetic procedures for younger groups increases. Doctors and marketers push GLP-1s on any and everyone regardless of clinical need. And Sydney Sweeneyâ€™s â€œgreat jeansâ€ American Eagle ad feels in conversation with Mike Tysonâ€™s fat shaming Super Bowl ad funded by Make America Healthy Again.

In addition, the needle hasnâ€™t moved much on Black women being labeled â€œaggressiveâ€ and facing microaggressions and outright racism on and off screen. Even in the show â€œThe Traitors,â€ Black contestants are given far less grace to prove themselves as â€œfaithfulsâ€ due to stereotypes being used as evidence of their integrity.

So many of us who watched ANTM growing up have done work to divorce ourselves from the limiting beliefs that the show and others instilled in us growing up. (For me, that looked like embracing my curves and natural hair.) But witnessing progressive ideas of beauty disappear in media while it simultaneously shames Banks feels a bit hypocritical.

Itâ€™s frustrating to see Banks refuse to take accountability for her wrongdoings and have the nerve to tease a Cycle 25 that may go to less extremes but will be likely to fall into old patterns. But whatâ€™s also true is that she is the perfect scapegoat for this moment to keep us comfortable in repeating the same mistakes. Thereâ€™s a regressiveness happening that we canâ€™t ignore. Today, itâ€™s a reality check that our favorite show perpetuated the same system it said it wanted to change. Tomorrow itâ€™s something far more sinister.Â 

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

These Black Women Went Into Debt For The Soft Life

The Big Problem With The "New" <em>ANTM</em>

The Rise Of AI Makes Me Ashamed Of My Features

title: 11 Reverse French Manicure Ideas That Put A Fresh Spin On A Classic
text:
11 Reverse French Manicure Ideas That Put A Fresh Spin On A Classic

When it comes toÂ my manicure, Iâ€™m pretty unadventurous.Â As soon as I sit down at my local salon, my nail tech knows exactly what to ask: â€œYourÂ usual French?â€ And the answer is always yes. To me, aÂ French manicureÂ â€” whether theÂ classic white tipÂ or something a bit cooler, likeÂ cat-eyeÂ â€” strikes the perfect balance between timeless and elevated, and it takes a lot to sway me from it. But the trending â€œreverseâ€ French manicure might just change that.Â 

What is the reverse French manicure?Â Â 

The reverse French manicureÂ isnâ€™tÂ exactly new, but we haveÂ Cardi Bâ€™s Super Bowl look to thank for its recent comeback. Her nail artist,Â Coca Michelle, turned the classicÂ French manicure on its headÂ â€” literally â€” byÂ flipping the gold tip so it curved around the base of the nail, right at the cuticle.Â Since then, Google searches for â€œreverse French manicureâ€ have increased by 110%, as it seems weâ€™re ready to channel Cardi B and try something different.Â 

Natalia Mercedes, nail artist and founder ofÂ Sad Girl Nails StudioÂ in New York City, is well-versed in the art of the reverse French manicure. â€œThe reverse French is essentially a flipped take on the classic,â€ she explains. â€œInstead of highlighting the tip of the nail, the design hugs the curve of the cuticle with either a thin, delicate line or a thicker, more graphic arc,â€ â€” exactly like this beautiful set by nail artist Fern Barron.Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Fern Barron (@barron.beauty)

Mercedes adds that it draws the eye downward. â€œIt frames the nail at its base rather than the edge, which gives it a more unexpected, editorial feel compared to the traditional French.â€Â 

She has an idea whyÂ itâ€™sÂ becoming so popular again: â€œItâ€™s a twist on a timeless look, and right now clients are craving fresh ways to stay minimal without feeling boring,â€ she says. To Mercedes, the reverse French feels modern and intentional â€” subtle, yet still a statement, like this set by Fliss Alton. â€œItâ€™sÂ perfect for someone who loves â€˜cleanâ€™ nails but wants something more directional than a standard tip,â€ adds Mercedes.Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by fliss alton | nail tech | nail educator (@gelsbyfliss)

How do you achieve the reverse French manicure?Â 

Achieving a reverse French manicure isÂ similar toÂ painting a traditional French tip. It calls for the precision of a thin nail brush and a steady, skilled handÂ as not to flood the cuticle with polish or get any uncured gel on the skin, which could potentially cause an allergic reaction.Â Â 

Thereâ€™sÂ a clever benefit toÂ reverse French nails,Â too,Â but it depends on your color choices:Â â€œIf you incorporate negative space or a sheerÂ nudeÂ atÂ the cuticle area, the grow-out can look incredibly subtle,â€ saysÂ Mercedes.Â Because the design is already anchored at the base, she adds that it can blend more seamlessly as the nail grows.Â â€œThis is especially true when softer tones are used,â€ she says, like nude shades.

Intrigued?Â Here are a few more of our favorite reverse French tip nail looks for your perusal.Â Â 

Polka-Dot Reverse FrenchÂ 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğğ² ğ‹ğ®ğœğ²-ğ‘ğ¨ğ¬ğ ğŸ¤ (@by.lucyrose)

Polka dots are the nail art trend du jour, but if youÂ donâ€™tÂ have the patience for a full look, ask your manicurist for a reverse French instead. This dainty design by Lucy Rose is so cute.Â 

Accent Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by fliss alton | nail tech | nail educator (@gelsbyfliss)

Nail artistÂ Fliss AltonÂ used TheÂ GelBottleâ€™sÂ BIAB in Teddy for the base, with Chalk Blue for the skinny French tip and the reverse French accent nail â€” a subtle switch-upÂ that feelsÂ refreshing.Â 

Negative Space Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nails By Jenny VanHoy (@jennyvanhoy83)

The glossy, clear base makes this burgundy reverse French â€” painstakingly painted byÂ Jenny VanHoyÂ â€” really pop.Â 

Tortie Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by The Nail Nerds (@thenailnerds_)

These tortoiseshell nails byÂ The Nail NerdsÂ are given a serious upgrade with a neon green reverse French, which draws the eye downward.Â 

Chunky Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Plaster. âš«ï¸ (@plasterbeauty)

The chunky cobalt blue reverse French over a jet-black base, finished with a slick of glossyÂ top coat, almost makes this set by Plaster look 3D.Â 

Double Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğğ² ğ‹ğ®ğœğ²-ğ‘ğ¨ğ¬ğ ğŸ¤ (@by.lucyrose)

Nail artist Lucy-Rose proves she has a steady hand with this double reverse French â€” a white slick of polish edged with a line of silverÂ chrome,Â all set against a peachy base.Â 

Chrome Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Gabriela Santiago (@gelpolish_bar)

This thick silver chrome reverse French by Gabriela Santiago looks stunning against a duck egg blue base.Â 

Micro Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by fliss alton | nail tech | nail educator (@gelsbyfliss)

Reverse French or nail cuffs â€” whatever you call the trend â€”Â Fliss Altonâ€™s super-skinny take is subtle and so chic.Â 

Gilt Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by PERTH BUILDER GEL â€“ GEL EXTENSIONS â€“ NAIL ART (@jellyjellynails_)

This gold reverse French byÂ Australia-based @jellyjellynails_Â is the manicure equivalent of stacking gold jewelry.Â 

Rose Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Christina â€¢ Colchester Nail Tech (@clw_nailartist)

Colchester-basedÂ nail tech ChristinaÂ knew the neon pink â€œcuticle cuffâ€ would perfectly complement the blush pink base of this set.Â 

Short Reverse French

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Charlotte May (@charlottemaynails)

Unlike the traditional French tip, the reverse French is much easier to master on shorter nails, like this set by manicuristÂ Charlotte May. We especially love theÂ sky blueÂ base and how the reverse French wraps around the tip slightly.

title: A Week In Chicago, IL On A $167,000 Salary
text:
A Week In Chicago, IL On A $167,000 Salary

Welcome to Money Diaries where we are tackling the ever-present taboo that is money. Weâ€™re asking real people how they spend their hard-earned money during a seven-day period â€” and weâ€™re tracking every last dollar.

If youâ€™d like to submit your own Money Diary, you can do so via our online form. We pay $150 for each published diary. Apologies but weâ€™re not able to reply to every email.

Editorâ€™s note: After a short hiatus, weâ€™re back once a week! Thank you for your patience. Weâ€™ll be honoring Money Diary submissions we received during our break by publishing them in the coming weeks. Thereâ€™s more to come soon â€” stay tuned.

This week: a marketing manager on $167,000 and who spends some of her money on some knitting yarn.

This Money Diary was written in the summer of 2025. This is a follow-up diary. You can read the original diary here.Â 

Occupation: Marketing manager
Industry: Life sciences
Age: 31
Location: Chicago, IL
Salary: $167,295 ($143,295 base + $24,000 bonus)
Joint Income/Financial Setup: Our joint income is around ~$240,000 (+/- $10k).Â My husband, F., is a freelance director of photography and has recently gone back to school to facilitate a career change to healthcare.Â Â Shortly after my first Money Diary we made the decision to combine our finances. It was a little challenging at first, but at the end of the day, we are a team, and we make financial decisions together. Combining finances has given us a clear picture of where we stand as a family and has allowed us to meet big financial goals like completely paying off our student loans last year. The way we manage our finances is that we plan our monthly budget off of my net income, and all money F. brings in goes into our liquid savings account.Â At the end of every month, we review our spending and sort everything into a spreadsheet with categories to track our spending habits and make sure weâ€™re staying on top of our financial goals.
Assets
Home value: $275,000
Car value: $20,000
Combined retirement accounts & investments: $250,848.52
Checking account: $1,785
Savings account: $66,612.60
Debt: $172,600 (home loan)
Paycheck Amount (2x/month): $3,252 (my husbandâ€™s varies)
Pronouns: She/her

Monthly Expenses
Housing Costs: $1,742.64 ($1,368 mortgage + $374 HOA).
Loan Payments: $0 (we paid off student loans last year)

All Other Monthly Expenses
Paycheck deductions (per paycheck):
Health/Life Insurance: $273
Investments: $1460

Recurring expenses
Utilities: $100
Subscriptions: $70
Gym membership for two: $154
Car insurance: $111
Mint mobile (2x lines): $53
Dog medication: $55

Was there an expectation for you to attend higher education? Did you participate in any form of higher education? If yes, how did you pay for it?
There was an expectation to attend college and get my bachelorâ€™s degree. However, I strayed away from getting a degree in anything that would require higher education because I was afraid of having to take on additional debt. I paid for undergrad with a combination of student loans, settlement money from a childhood injury, and some support from my parents. My husband F. is currently pursuing a career change with plans to go to med school. Seeing him in school definitely has me toying with going back and getting an MBA. My company has tuition reimbursement programs Iâ€™m looking into.

Growing up, what kind of conversations did you have about money? Did your parent(s) educate you about finances?
I did not receive a lot of education around money growing up. My parents made a handful of bad financial decisions and got into a lot of business debt owning their own small business. Tax-advantage accounts and employer 401(k)s were totally foreign to me when I first started working, but I think weâ€™ve done a good job building an investment portfolio given our financial backgrounds. My husband and I have done a lot to improve our financial literacy as adults and discuss our finances often.

What was your first job and why did you get it?
My first job out of college was working as a marketing coordinator at a PR agency. I got the job because I studied communications during college and snagged a paid internship between my junior and senior years. I worked as an intern until I graduated and was offered a full-time position. I was incredibly grateful to have a job lined up on day one of post-grad. My starting salary was $38k, which is wild to think about now! At the time, I was extremely careful with how I spent my money and even managed to save some on this salary.

Did you worry about money growing up?
Yes â€”Â looking back it is very clear to me that my parents were striving for a life that their careers could not afford. I grew up with a lot of insecurity around money, and feared that my peers would find out about my parentsâ€™ financial struggles and think less of me. Growing up this way definitely pushed me to strive for financial security and success as an adult.

Do you worry about money now?
No â€”Â I am very aware that we live a life that exceeded either of our expectations and feel confident in our current financial position and trajectory. Additionally, combining our accounts pushed me to take my emotions out of finances. I also know that Iâ€™m incredibly privileged to be able to think of money as a tool that allows us to live a comfortable life.

At what age did you become financially responsible for yourself and do you have a financial safety net?
I became financially responsible for myself the day I graduated college. My husband and I have built a financial safety net for ourselves through paying off loans, liquid savings, purchasing property, and investing in retirement accounts. Weâ€™ve been able to do all of this by living within our means through our 20s, and by prioritizing spending on long-term investments.

Do you or have you ever received passive or inherited income? If yes, please explain.
Yes. This past year we received a $10k gift from my grandfather. His health has declined and he is living with my parents, and sold all of his properties. The grandchildren all received a financial gift from the property sales.

Day One: Monday

8:00 a.m. â€” The temps have dropped so we are finally sleeping with the windows open but it means we had a noisier-than-usual night and didnâ€™t get great sleep. My husband, F., makes coffee while I browse white-noise machines. I notice that they are HSA/FSA eligible so make a note to come back for my purchase.Â 

8:30 a.m. â€” I boot up my computer for the week and check in with co-workers before I get ready to take the dog, P., around the block. I listen to my audiobook, Darling Girls, while I walk P. around the block. I love listening to audiobooks and love that you get 10 hours of listening included in your monthly Spotify Premium subscription!Â 

9:00 a.m. â€” I join my weekly round robin all-hands call as F. heads out for a job. My co-worker has the updates for my team this week so I just listen in while all teams give their updates and priorities for the week.Â 

9:30 a.m. â€” Next meeting of the morning! I hop on a call with all the product marketers on my team and we discuss what weâ€™re working on this week. For me, itâ€™s a few housekeeping tasks and a little bit of planning for future projects. I just wrapped up managing a big project and my manager is on paternity leave for the next two weeks, so itâ€™ll probably be a pretty slow week for me work-wise.Â 

10:00 a.m. â€” Itâ€™s time for breakfast! I take a break and listen to my audio book while I make myself eggs, toast, and a fruit bowl.

10:15 a.m. â€” My co-worker calls me asking for help with something. We also catch up and chat about whatâ€™s been going on in our lives since we last connected, and I eat my breakfast.Â 

10:30 a.m. â€” I spend the rest of the morning working on the task my co-worker and I chatted about.Â 

1:00 p.m. â€” I break for lunch and whip up a quick bowl of tuna salad. While Iâ€™m on my lunch break I scroll through Ravelry looking for a pattern to use up some extra yarn I have from a baby sweater project. A year ago, I really got into knitting and havenâ€™t stopped since I picked up knitting needles for the first time. I purchase a small neck scarf pattern called the My Jose Scarf. I cast on the project and knit a few stitches before logging back in for work.Â $8.20

3:00 p.m â€” Work is slowing down for the day so I decide to get a head start on dinner. F. and I have evening commitments so Iâ€™m hoping this will get dinner on the table faster. Dinner tonight is Pasta Alla Norma Sorta from NYT Cooking. F. comes home from his job and we catch up for a few minutes in the kitchen.

4:45 p.m. â€” I check my emails and Teams messages before riding my bike to group tennis lessons from 5-6 (I prepaid for the session a few weeks ago but itâ€™s typically $259 for 8x 60-minute lessons). I started taking tennis lessons last March and have fallen completely in love with the sport! Iâ€™m still very much a beginner tennis player, but Iâ€™ve signed up for my first ladiesâ€™ tennis league this fall. Expectations of winning are low, but Iâ€™m still planning on having fun!

6:15 p.m. â€” Back from tennis and F. is already settled into his online chemistry class. I check emails and Teams once more before logging off for the day and taking a shower. Iâ€™m grateful my past self did all the dinner prep. All thatâ€™s left to do is heat and assemble. I finish listening to my audiobook while I get dinner together.Â 

7:30 p.m. â€” F. has a break from his online class so we eat dinner together for a few minutes. F. recently decided on a career change and is finishing up some pre-reqs on online community college. The plan is to take the MCAT after this and then apply for med school (big life change)! After dinner, I clean up the kitchen, and walk P. once more before relaxing with my knitting project and watching reality TV for the rest of the evening.Â 

10:00 p.m. â€” We get ready for bed and read for a little while before falling asleep. F. is reading his chemistry textbook and Iâ€™m reading Fates and Furies by Lauren Groff.

Daily Total: $8.20

Day Two: Tuesday

6:30 a.m. â€” We wake up early today since F. has a job, so he needs to head out the door early this morning. F. makes coffee as I work through the NYT Games for the day. The Wordle really stumps me!

8:00 a.m. â€” I check in on my emails and check off a task for the day. F. heads out the door and I follow behind with P. I call my mom and catch up while I walk the dog. My mom lets me know that they are coming up to Chicago for Thanksgiving and this puts me in a good mood. Thanksgiving is my favorite holiday and I love to host!

9:00 a.m. â€” Iâ€™m back online for work for the rest of the morning. I get a CC alert that $20 has been reloaded on the city street parking account. F. must have arrived at his job (this is a work expense and we will get reimbursed from the client). I take a quick break to make breakfast and eat in front of my computer while responding to emails.

12:00 p.m. â€” During my lunch break I go to the public tennis courts near our condo and practice my serve for a while. As a beginner tennis player, serves are 100% the hardest skill to learn!

1:00 p.m. â€” On the way home from the courts I stop at my neighborhood market and grab a bell pepper, turkey, iceberg lettuce, olives, mozzarella, and black olives to make a chopped salad for lunch.Â $22.05

1:15 p.m. â€” When I get home I throw together my lunch salad and settle in for work for the rest of the afternoon. F. gets home from his job around 3 p.m. and makes salad with the ingredients I bought.Â 

4:00 p.m. â€” I get an email that my tennis league didnâ€™t have enough people sign up for the bracket and is being cancelled and refunded. I end up signing up for Gladiator Tennis, which Iâ€™ve heard of players using for league play. After my serve practice, Iâ€™m feeling hopeful I wonâ€™t totally embarrass myself and sign up for the beginner/intermediate league. $35

6:00 p.m. â€” The rest of the afternoon was spent working from the couch. I got my period and was majorly knocked down by cramps and PMS. F is already in class so I peel myself off the couch to walk P. around the block.Â 

7:30 p.m. â€” Dinner is leftovers from yesterday. F. eats while heâ€™s in online class and I eat while watching TV. I feel a little guilty about being so lazy this evening while F. is being productive in school.Â 

8:30 p.m. â€” F. wraps up class early so we walk P. around the neighborhood one more time, and then come home and wind down watching PBS before getting ready for bed.Â 

Daily Total: $57.05

Day Three: Wednesday

8:00 a.m. â€” We wake up and F. makes coffee while I play the NYT Games for the day and work on a few rows of knitting. F. talks about going to the gym this morning and I tell him I might come, too.

9:00 a.m. â€” I log onto my computer to get started on work for the day. The last week of August is usually my slowest week of the year, so there isnâ€™t a whole lot I need to be doing for the rest of the week. As a â€œhigh earnerâ€ with a WFH job, I feel a lot of guilt/shame around slow periods. November through July is generally very busy and then it slows down for a few months.Â 

10:00 a.m. â€” We take P. around the block and then head to the gym. I put on a spooky podcast when I get to the gym and do a leg workout.Â 

11:15 a.m. â€” F. makes eggs, toast, and fruit for us for breakfast when we get home and I do a little bit of work on my laptop.Â 

12:30 p.m. â€” I hop on a call to discuss landing pages that are being built for an upcoming campaign Iâ€™m managing. I often work with and project manage the digital and content teams and feel grateful that theyâ€™re a nice bunch of people to work with. We all give feedback and talk through some options for the Q4 campaign Iâ€™m leading.

1:30 p.m. â€” After my meeting, I take a quick little snack break and have some honey roasted almonds and remind myself to drink a glass of water. F. sees Iâ€™m up from my desk and also takes a study/snack break. We talk about going to Key West for his spring break in March. Weâ€™ve never been to Key West and weâ€™ve never taken a spring break before. I send F. a few links to the Key West Historic Inns once Iâ€™m back at my desk.

3:15 p.m. â€” Work is wrapping for the day andÂ I get a jump start on dinner since F. and I will be out for the evening. Tonightâ€™s dinner is chicken and rice from NYTimes Cooking.Â 

3:30 p.m. â€” While the chicken and rice is in the oven, I take P. out for a walk and clean up the kitchen a bit. F. and I sit down for an early dinner before getting ready to head out. After dinner, F. drops me off at tennis on his way to night class. One night a week heâ€™s in person for a lab.

6:00 p.m. â€” After tennis, my friend and I grab a drink at a wine bar in our neighborhood and cheers to playing well during class! $28.25

7:30 p.m. â€” I enjoy a nice late summer walk home through the neighborhood. August is the sweetest month of all and I always feel such a warm, fuzzy feeling walking around this time of year. Iâ€™m sure the wine was helping perpetuate this feeling!

8:15 p.m. â€” Home from tennis and I take an â€˜everything showerâ€™ before making a yogurt bowl and chilling with my knitting project while watching Southern Charm. I was turned on to Southern Charm after watching the latest season of The White Lotus. F. gets home around 9:30 p.m. and he fills me in on his first day of in-person class, and we hang out for a bit before getting ready for bed.

Daily Total: $28.25

Day Four: Thursday

7:30 a.m. â€” I wake up and get ready quickly for my first meeting of the day.Â 

8:00 a.m. â€” I meet with a colleague in Europe and we discuss projects weâ€™re collaborating on. F. makes coffee in the kitchen and we drink our coffee together after I wrap up my meeting.Â 

8:30 a.m. â€” F. asks if I ordered the sound machine yet (I havenâ€™t). We decide on an old school fan-based sound machine. I get started on a little bit of work and message with one of my coworkers about a final report for a project weâ€™re wrapping up. $60.63

10:00 a.m. â€” F. gets ready for the gym and I get ready to take the dogÂ on a walk. I walk F. to the gym and then stop at a local cafe for a breakfast sandwich before heading home and getting back to work.Â $14.79

12:30 p.m. â€” F. has been working on his chemistry homework all morning. Weirdly, the chem textbook does not come with an answer guide to check your work, so he purchases a used solutions manual to help him with studying.Â $27.44

1:00 p.m. â€” I have my weekly check-ins with two of my co-workers. We all agree itâ€™s been such a slow week but also nice to come up for air after our busy season this summer.Â 

3:00 p.m. â€” I have a psychiatrist appointment to check in on the anxiety medication Iâ€™m taking. I had a really scary panic attack where I ended up in the emergency room earlier this year so I have 100% been prioritizing my mental health. Anxiety is something Iâ€™ve struggled with since I was a kid and this year I feel like Iâ€™m finally taking the steps for treatment. Because Iâ€™ve hit my out of pocket max for the year, my co-pay is $0.Â 

3:45 p.m. â€” I stop for gas and at Whole Foods on my way home to pick up magnesium glycate (recommended by my psych for sleep) and a very balanced snack of cheese balls and a protein drink. I also grab some sugar thatâ€™ll I need for the baking project Iâ€™m working on this weekend. $73.25

5:30 p.m. â€” I wrap up work for the week and throw together a quick dinner of rice leftovers, broccoli, and shrimp from the freezer for F. and I to have before he has class, and I head out for my evening activity.Â 

6:30 p.m. â€” Every Thursday, my local knitting shop has a â€˜knit circleâ€™. This is the shop where I learned to knit a year ago and I really enjoy the community space theyâ€™ve built. I havenâ€™t been to knit night all summer so I make sure to bring a few of my finished objects to share. Vibes are great and I promise to myself Iâ€™ll be back again next week.Â 

8:30 p.m. â€” Home and snacking on the rest of the cheese balls while I watch TV and knit and F. finishes with his online class. Once heâ€™s done, we catch up and get ready for bed.Â 

Daily Total: $176.11

Day Five: Friday

8:00 a.m. â€” I have the day off so F. and I wake up a little later. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s a placebo, but I did sleep a lot better last night after taking the magnesium! F. and I have sex before getting out of bed and making coffee.Â 

10:00 a.m. â€” F. and I meet up with one of my friends to play some two-on-one. We play for about an hour and a half and itâ€™s so much fun. I love the endorphins I get from playing tennis.Â 

12:00 p.m. â€” Home from tennis and we have some breakfast. After knit night, Iâ€™m feeling inspired to order the boucle yarn I need to start a pattern I bought months ago. I also buy an extra skein of yarn for the scarf project Iâ€™m working on since it looks like Iâ€™m going to lose a game of yarn chicken.Â $165.15

1:30 p.m. â€” I shower and get ready to go to therapy. I go every other week, and to be honest, I find talk therapy a little bit tedious and exhausting but I go on the recommendation of my psychiatrist. I have to take the train because F. is about to head out of town for the weekend for a film festival. F. will be staying at his parentsâ€™ place and any expenses incurred, i.e. meals, etc., this weekend are business write-offs.Â 

2:00 p.m. â€” Once I get to the office I realize I messed up the dates and I actually donâ€™t have therapy until next week â€” whoops! Instead of therapy, I take a long walk through the neighborhood and stop at a few shops. I pick up three birthday cards and a baby card at Hazel â€”Â they have the best selection of cards.Â $25.91

2:30 p.m. â€” I make a few more shopping stops on my way home. Next stop is a local apothecary to pick up Ilia Limitless Lash Mascara. I also stop at the running store to pick up energy snacks for some of the tennis meetups and matches I have. Last stop is the grocery store to pick up a few ingredients for lunch, and baking ingredients to do a practice run of my friendâ€™s wedding cake Iâ€™m making in September.Â $77.62

5:00 p.m. â€” After the impromptu shopping afternoon, I come home and made a Costco frozen pizza. While the oven pre-heats and the pizza cooks I eat the broccoli leftovers from last night. I relax on the couch for a while before taking P. on a long walk. F. ended up taking the toll roads to Michigan since the holiday weekend traffic was looking bad.Â $17.10 (tolls).

6:30 p.m. â€” I spend a majority of the evening working on a practice cake for my friendâ€™s wedding next month. The recipe Iâ€™m using is Claire Saffitzâ€™s confetti cake â€”Â itâ€™s such a good recipe and is my go-to for the foster care birthday cakes I make volunteering.Â 

9:30 p.m. â€” Cake baking goes well but at this point Iâ€™ve made two failed attempts at marshmallow buttercream. I clean up the kitchen and decide that frosting the cake is a tomorrow task. I relax and watch TV while knitting the rest of the evening.Â 

Daily Total: $285.78

Day Six: Saturday

8:00 a.m. â€” P. wakes me up with a wet nose in the face and we snuggle in bed while I do the NYTimes Games. After this I get up and make a latte â€”still using the Breville Espresso Maker! While I drink my coffee, I crack open the holy grail cake cookbook, The Cake Bible by Rose Levy Beranbaum and scour the buttercream recipes until I find one that sounds like it will go well with the confetti cake.Â 

9:00 a.m. â€” I have a 10 a.m. tennis meet-up so I take P. around the block and make a quick breaky of scrambled eggs and fruit. Then I get ready and put a backpack together with my racket, waterbottle, knitting, and a book. Iâ€™m not going to go home right away after tennis.Â 

9:50 a.m. â€” I hop on my bike and arrive a few minutes early, hoping to snag a court, which I do! My tennis partner and I warm up and play a set. I lose 2-6, but still have fun and felt good about my serves.Â 

11:30 a.m. â€” First stop of the day after tennis is Loba. I get a housemade melon soda and a strawberry sourdough muffin. I settle in at a table to work on my knitting and start listening to a new audiobook, Donâ€™t Let Him In. Coincidentally, the two gals next to me were also knitting and we share a moment talking about what weâ€™re working on. The knitting community is alive and well in Chicago! $14.15

12:30 p.m. â€” Next stop is Paulina Meat Market to grab an Italian sub. Iâ€™m back on my bike headed towards the lake to enjoy my sandwich, and a little more knitting while I listen to the audiobook.Â $13.78

2:00 p.m. â€” I donâ€™t have enough butter in the fridge to do the meringue buttercream recipe so I stop at the local market on the way home and buy more butter. It kills me to buy butter at this price so I make a mental note to stock up at Costco next time. $6.64

2:15 p.m. â€” P. greets me at the door and I get straight to work prepping all the ingredients for the butter cream. All goes well with the new buttercream recipe and I finish up with the cake project for the weekend.Â 

4:30 p.m. â€” I take P. for a long walk to the river before the sun goes down. When I get home, I take a shower, clean up the kitchen and make tacos for dinner.Â 

7:30 p.m. â€” I try a slice of the cake I made and itâ€™s heavenly â€” canâ€™t wait to bring some to my friend tomorrow morning! The rest of the night is spent working on my knitting project and watching Southern Charm.

Daily Total:Â $34.57

Day Seven: Sunday

8:00 a.m. â€” P. wakes me up again and we snuggle in bed while I play the daily NYTimes Games.

8:30 a.m. â€” I make a latte and watch Sunday Morning while working on some knitting. After this, I walk P., have some breakfast, and get ready to meet up with a friend for tennis.Â 

10:00 a.m. â€”Â We donâ€™t have to wait long for an open court, thankfully! My friend and I have a nice long warm-up and then play a match. I get my a** handed to me and lose 6-0, 6-0. I still have fun and score a few points and remind myself the only way to get better is to keep playing!

12:00 p.m. â€”Â After tennis, I go home, take a shower, and get the laundry for the week started. Our condo building doesnâ€™t have in-unit hook-ups, so weâ€™re still using coin-operated in the basement. Itâ€™s not glamorous but it gets the job done.Â $4.50

1:30 p.m. â€” F. is home from his weekend away and Iâ€™m starving for lunch! We go on a long walk through the neighborhood and get sandwiches and Diet Cokes at L&M, which we eat in the park and catch each other up on our weekends.Â $37.42

3:30 p.m. â€”Â When we get home from lunch we have some of the cake I made yesterday. F. gives his best Paul Hollywood critique. The rest of the afternoon is spent working on knitting projects and watching TV. Iâ€™m pretty tired from the two hours of tennis. F. takes a nap and works on his chemistry homework for a bit.Â 

6:00 p.m. â€” F. and I walk P. around the block. When we get home we open a bottle of wine and have the tacos from yesterday for dinner. We chat for a bit before F. resumes his chem homework and I get back to knitting.Â 

Daily Total: $41.92

Money Diaries are meant to reflect an individualâ€™s experience and do not necessarily reflect Refinery29â€™s point of view. Refinery29 in no way encourages illegal activity or harmful behavior.

The first step to getting your financial life in order is tracking what you spend â€” to try on your own, check out our guide to managing your money every day. For more Money Diaries, click here.

Do you have a Money Diary youâ€™d like to share? Submit it with us here.

Have questions about how to submit or our publishing process? Read our Money Diaries FAQ doc here or email us here.

title: 14 Niacinamide Skincare Products To Try For Clearer, Brighter Skin
text:
14 Niacinamide Skincare Products To Try For Clearer, Brighter Skin ForÂ virtually allÂ of my teen years, I blasted my face with salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide â€” anything that claimed to targetÂ acne,Â I slathered with reckless abandon. ItÂ wasn'tÂ until my 20s that I finally put down the harsh products and picked up gentler ones that targeted breakouts without the slash-and-burn-farming approach â€” this is how I discoveredÂ niacinamide.Â 
Â 
If you ask me, niacinamideÂ (a form of vitamin B3)Â is well-deserving of its hype,Â andÂ itâ€™sÂ not unusual to see it laced into not only skincare products, byÂ makeup primers, skin tints, and foundationsÂ nowadays.Â The ingredientÂ isÂ often name-checkedÂ by dermatologists for its multifaceted benefits: curbing excess oil, minimizing the appearance ofÂ largeÂ poresÂ andÂ fine lines, and soothing flare-ups due to inflammation or acne.Â Â 
Â 
â€œNiacinamide works by modulating inflammation and supporting the skin barrier, which is especially important for acne-prone and reactive skin,â€ explains dermatologist Jenna Queller, MD.Â She adds,Â â€œIt also helps regulate sebum productionÂ [natural oils produced by the skin], reduce the transfer of pigment within the skin, and improve skin elasticity, contributing to brighter, more even-toned skin over time.â€Â In other words,Â it'sÂ an all-in-one skincare ingredient with near-universal appeal.Â 
Â 
Ahead,Â I'veÂ rounded up some of my favorite products thatÂ includeÂ the star ingredient â€” from niacinamide cleansers to serums to moisturizers.Â 

At Refinery29, weâ€™re here to help you navigate this overwhelming world of stuff. All of our market picks are independently selected and curated by the editorial team. All product details reflect the price and availability at the time of publication. If you buy or click on something we link to on our site, Refinery29 may earn commission.

title: Meritâ€™s New Blurring Lipstick Is The Comfiest Youâ€™ll Ever Wear â€” Trust Me
text:
Meritâ€™s New Blurring Lipstick Is The Comfiest Youâ€™ll Ever Wear â€” Trust Me

I startedÂ wearing makeupÂ at 13, but I can count on one hand the lipsticksÂ Iâ€™veÂ used all the way to the last swipe. Over the years, very few have ever given me exactly what I want â€” and IÂ donâ€™tÂ thinkÂ Iâ€™mÂ asking for much. I want my lipstick to feel moisturizing on myÂ chronically dry lips, stay where I put it without ending up on my teeth, lend aÂ soft, blurred, diffused effect, and not break the bank entirely.Â Thatâ€™sÂ exactly whyÂ Iâ€™veÂ fallen head over heels forÂ Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush.Â 

WhatÂ isÂ Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush and what are the benefits?Â 

Signature Lip BlushÂ is the latest addition to Meritâ€™sÂ growingÂ lip lineup. You might know â€” and love â€”Â itsÂ Signature Lipstick,Â which occupies a cozy space between matte and glossy, giving lips a subtle satin-like glint. OrÂ perhaps theÂ Shade Slick lip oilÂ is a staple in your handbag.Â SignatureÂ Lip Blush, however, dials the shine all the way back.Â 

Merit describesÂ SignatureÂ Lip BlushÂ as a â€œsheer matte lightweight, buildable formula with a comfortable, balm-like feelâ€.Â To me,Â itâ€™sÂ a soft matte lipstickÂ thatâ€™sÂ notÂ tooÂ dissimilar from a lip stain â€” packed with pigment â€” or a lip pencil, which you can diffuse with your fingers or a brush.Â Â 

IfÂ youâ€™reÂ just as obsessed as I am with celebrity makeup artistÂ Nina Park, specifically the way she makes her clientsâ€™ lips appear contoured, plump, and diffused, then I have a feelingÂ youâ€™reÂ going to love this lipstick. On application,Â itâ€™sÂ sheer and light enough to blend outward, but unlike others with a similar texture, once it dries down a little, it clings to lips forÂ a good fourÂ hours without disappearing into nothingness.Â 

Thatâ€™sÂ all down to what Merit calls gel-wrapped pigments â€”Â essentially moleculesÂ of color encapsulated in a gel-like texture that makes swiping and blending easy.Â Speaking of color, thereÂ are eight shades in total, spanning Andie (aÂ delicateÂ petal pink) to Gamay (aÂ deepÂ red wine). Here,Â Iâ€™mÂ wearing September, a muted terracotta, paired with Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Liner in Mayfair, a peachy mauve.Â I will say the lipstick bullet appears a little darker than it does on the lips.

Merit Signature Lip Blush Lightweight Lip Blush, $28Â 

What makes Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush Special?Â 

What setsÂ Meritâ€™sÂ SignatureÂ Lip BlushÂ apart from other soft matte lipsticks is how it feels on. Most matte products dry out my parched lips even further,Â settling intoÂ â€” and accentuating â€”Â lines and creases.Â This one feelsÂ soÂ comforting,Â itâ€™sÂ like wearing a lip balm â€” all without any stickiness. You can thank sesame seed extract, nourishing olive oil, and plant-based waxes for that.Â 

I judge makeupÂ first and foremostÂ on how it makes me feel, but when others notice,Â itâ€™sÂ affirming.Â Since givingÂ Signature Lip BlushÂ a trial run these past few weeks,Â Iâ€™veÂ had countless compliments on myÂ lipstick, with beauty editor peers repeatedly asking whatÂ Iâ€™mÂ wearing â€”Â weâ€™reÂ convinced it makes my lips appear bigger.Â 

What to know about Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush:

â€¢Â Sheer, matte lipstick with a moisturizing balm-like feel.Â 

â€¢Â Available in eight shades from rose brown through toÂ bordeaux.Â Â 

â€¢Â Â Lends a diffused, blurred finish to lips and stays put for hours.Â 

How do you use Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush?Â 

BecauseÂ Signature Lip Blush isÂ so balm-like, IÂ donâ€™tÂ have to be precise when IÂ applyÂ it. Usually, IÂ lineÂ my lips and even use a lip brush before any lipstick, but with this, I can swipe it on haphazardly â€” without a mirror â€” and still end up with perfect, pillowy lips.Â Maybe thatâ€™sÂ the blurred-lip trend talking, but the texture makes it so easy.Â 

IfÂ youâ€™reÂ applying it a little more thoughtfully, it looks even better paired with a darker lip pencil and blurred ever so slightly over the lines,Â againÂ lending that Nina Park effect. I love that the lipstick bullet boasts aÂ squovalÂ shape, which makes light work of tracing your lip line if youÂ donâ€™tÂ have a lip pencil to hand.Â 

Ultimately, thisÂ is the perfect lipstick for lipstick skeptics and obsessives alike â€” low-maintenance, wearable, and hard to mess up.Â I currently have three in my handbag.

Where can you get Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush?Â 

You can buy Meritâ€™s Signature Lip Blush atÂ Sephora.comÂ or fromÂ Meritbeauty.com.Â

The Best Haircut Trends From New York Fashion Week New York might be painfully cold, but thatÂ hasnâ€™tÂ stopped the fashion pack from dressing up and descending on the cityâ€™s icy thoroughfares.Â Â 

From boxy blazers to leather trenches, this seasonâ€™s street style is a lesson in mastering outfits for freezing conditions â€” butÂ itâ€™sÂ the haircuts that are really catching our attention.Â 

Butterfly layers, bluntÂ bobs,Â and grown-out pixies are just a handful of the cutsÂ weâ€™veÂ spotted so far, and as the week continues,Â weâ€™reÂ expecting plenty more.Â Â

title: Pisces Season Is Here â€” & Drama Is Incoming
text:
Pisces Season Is Here â€” & Drama Is Incoming

Rejoice! As we enter Pisces season, weâ€™re also getting closer to spring. From February 18th to March 20th, the sun will be splashing around in the enigmatic water sign of Pisces, heightening our intuition, and creativity. This year, Pisces season brings wisdom, reflection, and a lot of wildness in between. Things are going to get messy, so prepare for the drama-of-it-all. Before we get sea sick from the rapid changes, itâ€™s important to learn how to flow with ease through the turbulent waters ahead. Luckily, the stars and planets will help us predict the journey.

In previous years, Saturn and Neptune have added restriction and paranoia to the mix when the sun was in Pisces. Now, Saturn and Neptune are in Aries, still stirring up problems, but not making us insecure and unsure about the road ahead. February 20th brings the conjunction of the two, urging us to pursue our dreams at any cost â€” even if it means hurting others in the process. We arenâ€™t going to stand idly by and watch situations unfold; weâ€™re going to take an active approach to drive change. We are more confident, aggressive, tenacious, and tougher than before.

For the first part of the solar return, there will be a stellium in mystical Pisces (the sun, Mercury, Venus, and Mars). Weâ€™ll be stubborn in our delusions, only accepting our reality as the correct one, which is problematic. As a result, arguments can ensue, especially if we do not back down. Finding the middle ground is useful; however, itâ€™ll be difficult to understand others when we put our desires first and throw logic out the window. Taking a beat to center our energy requires patience and consideration â€” sentiments we may be lacking in the heat of the moment.Â 

Mercury retrograde in Pisces begins on February 26th and lasts until March 20th, when the sun ingresses into Aries, and the spring equinox melts the ice away. The Mercurial moonwalk is going to raise our anxieties from the immense miscommunications and frenetic vibes. The universe wants us to go inwards, allowing us to focus on internal healing. Former partners will resurface, promising the world, when they have no intention of staying. Things are feeling intangible, and the wishy-washiness makes us lose our way. Choosing compassion connects us to people and gives us the strength to rise above the tides.

The total lunar eclipse in Virgo on March 3rd keeps our head above water by offering a chance to have a pragmatic approach to resolving matters. The blood moon is letting us see through the darkness, like a lighthouse illuminates the ocean, keeping us afloat. The caveat is that lunar eclipses are fast and furious, so the information being brought to our attention might shake us up, forcing us to make decisions. The retrograde pauses us from being direct or able to cut off the negativity, leaving us riddled with confusion, disillusionment, and frustration. I told you it was going to be chaotic!Â 

DashDividers_1_500x100

Key Astrological Dates For Pisces Season:Â 

February 18th: The sun enters Pisces, making us tender, imaginative, romantic, and sentimental. Our hearts and emotions guide the way forward.

February 20th: Saturn conjuncts Neptune in Aries, allowing this once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon to bring evolution and a metamorphosis on a global level. Outdated systems fall and new ones emerge.

February 26th: Mercury Retrograde in Pisces commences, bringing travel issues, missed texts or emails, and the revival of old foes or exes for another hurrah (if we let them).Â 

March 2nd: Mars enters Pisces, pushing us to rebel and assert our views â€” although, weâ€™ll have a few doubts about what we want to fight for or pursue.

March 3rd: The lunar eclipse in Virgo is a moment of clarity and truth. How we react and deal with the energy will augment and shift our lives.Â 

March 6th: Venus enters Aries, motivating us to take the lead in relationships and to pursue our dreams.

March 10th: Jupiter in Cancer ends the retrograde cycle that began on November 11th, 2025. Abundance and luck are coming!

March 18th: The New Moon in Pisces is an opportunity to manifest our hopes and goals for the new season that comes two days later.

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

Your February Horoscope Is Here

title: The Best New York Fashion Week Street Style Looks
text:
The Best New York Fashion Week Street Style Looks The streets of New York City are swelling with waves of fashion's finest, thanks to the New York Fashion Week Autumn/Winter 2026 season. From front-row celebrities and models to media personalities and journalists, the fashion-obsessed are proudly showing off their outfits. From tons of layers, dramatic fur coats, statement hats, and tried-and-true boots, bundling up has never looked so chic.

Photographer Flordalis Espinal shot her favorite looks and hairstyles from NYFW, capturing the joy and style across the city. Outside of presentations and runways like Alexis Bittar, Christian Siriano, Cinq Ã  Sept, Coach, Collina Strada, and Zankov, see the best street style looks (so far) ahead.
